Chapter 4, Section 4: Discrimination of Karma. The sÅ«tra says, Karma is of four kinds: there is karma with black black ripening, there is karma with white white ripening, there is karma with black and white black and white ripening, and there is karma that is neither black nor white with neither black nor white ripening, able to exhaust all karma.
What are their characteristics?
Verse:
Based on the distinctions of black-black, etc., the four kinds of karma are explained.
Bad form and wholesome in the desire realm, able to exhaust them, are without outflows.
One should know that they are called black, white, both black and white, and neither black nor white, respectively.
Commentary:

The Buddha, based on the differences in the nature and class of the results of karma, and the distinctions between what is to be eliminated and the eliminator, explains black-black, etc., as the four.
All unwholesome karma is called entirely black, because of its defiled nature. Its ripening is also black, because it is undesirable.
Good action of the realm of form is called white, because it is not mixed with evil, and its retribution is also white, because it is agreeable.
Why is it not said that good action of the realm of formlessness is white?

It is said that where there are two kinds of retribution, i.e., intermediate existence and rebirth existence, and where there are three kinds of action, i.e., bodily, vocal, and mental, then it is said that there is good action, but not where these are absent.
However, there is a scripture that says,
Good action of the realm of desire is called black and white, because it is mixed with evil, and its retribution is also black and white, because it is mixed with disagreeable results.
The terms black and white are established on the basis of a continuum, not on the basis of their own nature.
Why is this?
Because there is no single action or single retribution that is black and also white, because these are mutually contradictory.
Isnâ€™t it the case that the results of evil action are mixed with the results of good action? In that case, the results of good action should also be called black and white.

The results of bad action are not necessarily mixed with the results of good action, but the results of good action in the realm of desire are definitely mixed with the results of bad action, because evil is superior to good in the realm of desire.
The first three kinds of karma are called nonblack because they are not defiled, and they are called nonwhite because they do not summon white retribution.
The word nonwhite is an intentional statement, because the Buddha said to Ä€nanda in the MahÄÅ›Å«nyatÄsÅ«tra,
The dharmas of the adepts are pure good, pure white, and absolutely without sin.
The Abhidharma-Å›Ästra also says,
What are the white dharmas?

They are the wholesome dharmas, the nondefiled indeterminate dharmas without retribution, because they do not fall into the realms and because they are contrary to the nature of the transmigratory dharmas.
Are all pure karmas able to extinguish the first three kinds of karma?
No, they are not.
How is it?
The verse says:
The four forbearances of the dharma and the desire realm, and the first eight uninterrupted paths,
The twelve pure thoughts only extinguish pure black karma.
The ninth uninterrupted thought of the desire realm and the four meditations,
One completely eliminates the mixed and pure black, and four cause the pure white to be completely eliminated.
The treatise says:

In the path of seeing, the four forbearances of dharma knowledge and the eight uninterrupted paths in the stage of detachment from the desire realm, together with the twelve thoughts, only eliminate the pure black. The one pure thought accompanying the ninth uninterrupted path in detachment from the desire realm causes both the black and white and the pure black to be completely eliminated, because at this time it generally eliminates the wholesome dharmas of the desire realm, and also eliminates the ninth unwholesome karma.
The four pure thoughts accompanying the ninth uninterrupted path in detachment from each of the four meditations only cause the pure white karma to be completely eliminated.
Why can the wholesome dharmas of the various stages only be eliminated by the final path and not by others?
Because wholesome dharmas are not eliminated by their own nature, because those that have been eliminated may still appear in the present.
However, when the afflictions that take them as objects are eliminated, it is said that those wholesome dharmas are eliminated, because at that time the wholesome dharmas attain freedom from bondage.

Therefore, as long as even one category of the passions that have it as their object remains, the meaning of severing the bonds is not established, because at that time the good law has not yet been freed from the bonds.
A verse says:ğŸ”½Some say that in hell, the rest of the desire realm are black and mixed karma.
Some say that in the desire realm, karma to be experienced after being reborn in the realm of desire and to be experienced after leaving that realm are black and mixed karma, respectively.
The treatise says:
Other masters say:
Karma to be experienced in hell and karma to be experienced in the rest of the desire realm are called pure black and mixed karma, respectively.
This is because the retribution of hell is produced only by unwholesome karma, and therefore karma to be experienced in hell is called pure black karma.

With the exception of hell, the retribution of the rest of the desire realm is produced by both wholesome and unwholesome karma, and therefore karma to be experienced in the rest of the desire realm is called black and white karma.
Other masters say:ğŸ”½Karma to be experienced after being reborn in the realm of desire and to be experienced after leaving that realm are called pure black and mixed karma, respectively.

This is because karma to be experienced after being reborn in the realm of desire is not mixed with wholesome karma and is therefore called pure black karma. Karma to be experienced after leaving the realm of desire is both wholesome and unwholesome and is therefore called black and white karma.
Also, a scripture says, â€œThere are three kinds of muni.â€ Also, a scripture says, â€œThere are three kinds of purity, which are of body, speech, and mind.â€
What are their characteristics?
Verse:
The three kinds of muni are the three pure actions of body, speech, and mind of post-learners.
It should be known that the three kinds of purity are the three kinds of good conduct.
Commentary:
The bodily and verbal actions of post-learners are called the muni of body and speech. The muni of mind is the post-learner's mind, not mental action.
Why is this?
The ultimate muni has only mind as its essence. It is inferred from the two actions of body and speech.
Also, the bodily and verbal actions are the substance of separation, but mental action is not so, because there is no indication.
The muni is established by the meaning of separation. Therefore, the mind is called muni because it can separate from something by means of bodily and verbal actions.
Why is the muni only in post-learners?
Because the arhat is the true muni, because the words of the afflictions are eternally tranquil.
The three kinds of good conduct of body, speech, and mind are called the three kinds of purity of body, speech, and mind.
They are called pure because one is temporarily or permanently separated from all evil conduct and the defilements.
These two are taught in order to stop sentient beings from imagining that there are wrong sages and wrong purity.
Also, a scripture says that there are three kinds of evil conduct, and it also says that there are three kinds of good conduct, all of which are of body, speech, and mind.
What are their characteristics?
A verse says:
Evil conduct of body, speech, and mind are called the three kinds of evil conduct.
The three kinds of good conduct are the opposite of these.
The treatise says:
All unwholesome bodily, verbal, and mental actions are respectively called the evil conduct of body, speech, and mind.
However, there are three kinds of evil mental conduct: covetousness, malice, and wrong views, because covetousness, etc., have a substance separate from volition.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:
Greed, hatred, and false views are mental actions, because the SiÌ„nï¬rï¬saÌ„miÌ„ Sutra says that these three are mental actions.
If this is so, then action and the passions would be identical.
What is wrong with saying that the passions are mental actions?
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say that this is not reasonable.
If you admit this, then you contradict many reasonings and doctrines and commit a great error.

The reason that the scriptures say that these are mental actions is that they are the door of thought, because they are able to attract undesirable results, and because they are condemned by the wise.
These actions are evil, and therefore they are called evil actions.
The three good actions should be understood in the opposite sense.
That is, all good actions of body, speech, and thought.
Good actions are not noncovetousness, nonhatred, and right views.
Since right views and wrong views are not actions, how can they be good or bad?
Because they are the roots of benefit and harm.
Also, a scripture says:
There are ten courses of action, some good and some bad.
What are their characteristics?
A verse says:
The ten courses of action are included in good and evil conduct,
And their natures are the gross and obvious, which become good or evil as appropriate.
The treatise says:
Among the good and evil conduct explained above, if they are gross, obvious, and easy to know, they are included in the ten courses of action.
As appropriate, if they are good, they include the good conduct, and if they are bad courses of action, they include the evil conduct.
What kinds of good and evil conduct are not included?

First, among the evil bodily actions, the course of bodily evil action does not include one part, namely, the preliminary and subsequent parts of other evil bodily actions, such as drinking alcohol, beating, binding, and so on, because the preliminary and subsequent parts are not gross and obvious.

If bodily evil actions cause other sentient beings to lose their lives, lose their wealth, or lose their wives and concubines, they are called courses of action in order to make one stay far away from them.
The path of verbal evil actions does not include the preparatory and subsequent stages and the light [forms of evil actions].
The path of mental evil actions does not include the evil thoughts and the light greed, etc.

Among the paths of good actions, the path of good bodily actions does not include one part of good bodily actions, namely, the preparatory and subsequent stages and other good bodily actions, such as abstaining from drinking alcohol and making offerings.
The path of good verbal actions does not include one part of good verbal actions, namely, affectionate speech, etc.
The path of good mental actions does not include one part of good mental actions, namely, all good thoughts.
Are the first seven paths of action all definitely with both indication and non-indication?
No, it is not so.
How is it?
The verse says:
The six evil [paths of action] are definitely without indication, and if one does it oneself, there are two [indications].
The seven good [paths of action] are received at birth, and the two [paths of action] born from concentration are only without indication.
The treatise says:

Among the seven unwholesome courses of action, the first six definitely have both manifest and unmanifest forms, namely killing, taking what is not given, false speech, divisive speech, harsh speech, and frivolous speech.
If one sends others to do these six kinds of evil, when the fundamental action is completed, one does not have manifest form.
If one does these six courses of action oneself, then all six have both manifest and unmanifest forms, because when one initiates the manifest action, the other person dies, etc.;
if they die later, it is the same as sending an emissary, because when the fundamental action is completed, there is only unmanifest form.
Only sexual misconduct definitely has both kinds, because it must be completed by one's own body and cannot be done by sending an emissary, just as one does not experience pleasure oneself.
If the seven wholesome courses of action arise from precepts, they must all have both manifest and unmanifest forms, because morality arising from precepts must be based on manifest form.

The precepts included in the meditative absorptions and the pure precepts are called precepts born of concentration. They only have unmanifest form, because they are only born from the power of the mind.
Are the preparatory and subsequent actions the same as the fundamental action?
It is not so.
How is it?
The verse says:
The preparatory stage definitely has expression, and the unexpressed may or may not exist.
The subsequent stage is the opposite of this.
The treatise says:
The preparatory stage of the karmic path definitely has expression. The unexpressed in this stage may or may not exist.
If it arises from intense entanglements and pure mind, then there is the unexpressed. Otherwise, there is none.
The subsequent stage is the opposite of the former. It definitely has the unexpressed. The expressed action in this stage may or may not exist.
If at a later time one gives rise to what follows the former action, then there is expressed action. Otherwise, there is none.
Within this meaning, how is the stage of preparation, the fundamental stage, and the subsequent stage established?

As for the first of the unwholesome actions, killing, when a butcher is about to kill a sheep, he first gives rise to the thought of killing, gets up from his bed, takes the price of the sheep, goes to the market, touches the body of the sheep, pays the price and takes it away, leads it back to the slaughterhouse, takes a stick or knife, beats or stabs it once or twice, until its life is not yet ended, all of this is called the preparatory action of killing.
Following this manifest action, when the sheep's life ends, the manifest and unmanifest actions at that moment are called the fundamental path of action of killing.
For two reasons, sentient beings are touched by the sin of killing as a fundamental path of action:
First, because of the preparatory action; second, because the result is fulfilled.
After that moment, the unmanifest action of killing continues without interruption, called the subsequent action of killing.

And at a later time, when it is skinned, butchered, washed, weighed, sold, cooked, or eaten, and the manifest action of praising its deliciousness at that moment is also called the subsequent action of killing.
The other six kinds of paths of action are also divided into three parts, and the explanation should be understood by analogy.
When craving, hatred, and false views are present, they are called fundamental paths of action. Therefore there is no distinction of preparatory and subsequent activity.
Here it should be explained.
When the being to be killed is in the state of death, does the action of killing at that moment of the killer constitute the path of action?
Or is it after death?
If so, what is wrong with that?
Both are faulty.

If the being to be killed is in the state of death, and the action of killing constitutes the path of action, then the killer and the being to be killed would both die at the same time, and the killer would constitute the path of action.
However, our school does not allow that path of action to be established.
If the being to be killed dies later, and the action of killing constitutes the path of action, then this would not correspond to the previous statement:
According to this manifest action, they die.
The manifest and unmanifest actions in this moment are called the fundamental path of action of killing.
Moreover, it should contradict the VaibhÄá¹£ika interpretation of the original treatise, which states:
Is there killing where the life has already been harmed but the killing has not yet ceased?
He said:
Yes, like when the life has already been cut off but the preparatory action has not yet ceased.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas interpret this passage as follows:
Here, the subsequent action is referred to by the term preparatory action.
It should be said that the preparatory action is referred to by the term fundamental action, because it is admitted that after the end of life, the fundamental [action] has not yet ceased.
Like this, there is no fault here. This should be explained.
What is called faultless here?
It means referring to the fundamental action by the term preparatory action.
If so, how can the manifest action at that time be established as the fundamental path of action?
Why is it not established?
Because it is useless.
What use is there for the unmanifest in this case?
Therefore the path of action is completed not by the performance of the action but by the completion of the result. At that time, both the preparatory action and the path of action are completed.
Moreover, the various paths of action may mutually become preparatory and subsequent actions.
Now we must explain how the path of killing may be the preparatory action for the ten paths of action.

That is, suppose a person wishes to kill an enemy and devises a plan to kill him, or he kills living beings in order to pray for help, or he steals the property of another in order to use it to kill, or he commits sexual misconduct with the wife of another in order to get her to kill her husband, or he commits the four kinds of verbal evil in order to create dissension in the relationship of the other with his friend.

Even if he has the power to save, he has no intention to do so; or he covets the property of another; or he arouses a mind of anger toward the other; or he nourishes the action of killing by means of false views. Then he kills. This is called the preparatory action for killing consisting of the ten paths of action.

Having killed the enemy, he later kills his relatives, seizes his property, and lusts after his wife. He then gives rise to greed, ill-will, and wrong views in succession. These ten are called the subsequent actions of killing.
The remaining karmic paths should be understood accordingly.

Greed, etc., should not be able to serve as the preliminary action, because the preliminary action is not accomplished merely by the arising of the mind, because nothing is done when the mind alone arises.
Moreover, a sÅ«tra says:
Bhiká¹£us should know that killing has three kinds:
One arises from greed, one arises from ill-will, and one arises from delusion.
Up to wrong views also have three kinds.
Here it should be explained:
What are the characteristics of killing?
It is called arising from greed.
The same question is asked of the others.
Not all karmic paths are completed by all three roots, but their preliminary actions are not the same as those.
How are they not the same?
The verse says:
The preliminary actions arise from the three roots, because they give rise to those without interruption.
The three roots of greed, etc., arise.
The treatise says:
When the preparatory stages of the unwholesome paths of action arise, each arises from the three unwholesome roots. This is said based on their prior instigation.

The preparatory stage of killing that arises from greed is like when one kills in order to obtain their body parts, or in order to obtain wealth, or for the sake of amusement, or in order to rescue a friend or oneself. Killing arises from greed.
Arising from hatred is like when one kills an enemy in order to eliminate them, giving rise to the preparatory stage of killing with a hateful mind.

Arising from delusion is like when one gives rise to the preparatory stage of killing with a mind that considers it to be the Dharma in a sacrifice, or when kings and others, based on worldly laws, punish enemies and eliminate criminals, considering it to be a great merit and giving rise to the preparatory stage of killing.
Moreover, the PÄrasÄ«kas say:
If one ends the lives of old and sick parents to spare them from suffering, one will give rise to supreme merit.
Moreover, some non-Buddhists say:
Snakes, scorpions, bees, and so on are harmful to people. If one can kill them, one will generate superior merit.
Sheep, deer, water buffalo, and other animals are originally intended for food, so killing them is not a sin.
Moreover, due to wrong views, one kills sentient beings. These preparatory actions all arise from delusion.

The preparatory action of stealing arising from greed is when one steals with a preparatory action according to one's needs, or for the sake of other benefits, respect, fame, or in order to rescue oneself and one's friends, and thus arouses the preparatory action of stealing from greed.
That arising from anger is when, in order to eliminate an enemy, one gives rise to an angry mind and arouses the preparatory action of stealing.
That arising from delusion is when kings and others, relying on the laws of the world, take the wealth of evil people, thinking it is proper and there is no sin of stealing.
Moreover, Brahmins say:
In the beginning of the eon, the Great Brahma King gave the wealth of the world to the Brahmins. Later, the Brahmins' power became weak, and they were invaded and used by the low castes.

Now, when Brahmins in the world rob or steal the property of others, using it to sustain themselves, to give to others, or for other purposes, they all use their own property and do not commit the sin of stealing.

However, when they take it, they have the thought of others' property. Moreover, due to wrong views, they steal others' property. All of these are called the preparatory actions of stealing arising from delusion.

The preparatory actions of sexual misconduct arising from greed are as follows: When one has a defiled mind towards the wives of others, or in order to seek others' wealth, fame, status, and respect, or in order to save oneself or others, one gives rise to the preparatory actions of sexual misconduct from a mind of attachment.
Arising from hatred means, for example, to engage in sexual misconduct out of a mind of anger in order to eliminate an enemy.
Arising from delusion means, for example, like ParÄÅ›ara praising the practice of non-celibacy with one's mother and so forth.

Moreover, Brahmins praise the cow sacrifice, in which the women and men who observe the cow vow suck water and chew grass, either standing or walking, without distinguishing between relatives and strangers, engaging in sexual intercourse with whomever they encounter.
Moreover, non-Buddhists say:
All women are like pestles, flowers, ripe fruit, cooked food, stairs, roads, bridges, and boats, which should be used by the people of the world.
These preparatory actions arise from delusion.
The four courses of verbal action such as false speech, etc., that arise from craving and hatred should be explained in the same way as above.
However, the preparatory actions for false speech that arise from delusion are like what is said in the non-Buddhist treatises:
If a person, for the sake of amusement and laughter, marriage, the queen,
and saving life and wealth, utters false speech, there is no sin.
Moreover, the preparatory actions for false speech, divisive speech, etc. that arise from wrong views should be known as all arising from delusion.
Moreover, all the Vedas and other false treatises are included in frivolous speech, and their preparatory actions arise from delusion.
Since the three such as craving have no preparatory actions, how can it be said that they arise from craving, etc.?
Because they arise immediately after the three roots, it can be said that craving, etc. arise from the three roots.

From non-delusion, sometimes from one, sometimes from two, sometimes from three.
The unwholesome ones are produced from the three roots.
How about the wholesome ones?
The verse states:
In the three stages, the wholesome ones are all produced from the three roots of wholesomeness.
The treatise states:

The preparatory, fundamental, and subsequent actions of the wholesome courses of action are all produced from the wholesome roots of non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion, because the three stages of the wholesome are all what is produced by the wholesome mind, and because the wholesome mind necessarily corresponds with the three kinds of wholesome roots.

translated: It means being far removed from the three stages of the unwholesome. Being free from the preparatory actions of evil is precisely the preparatory action of the wholesome. Being free from the fundamental evil is precisely the fundamental wholesome. Being free from the subsequent evil is precisely the subsequent wholesome.

For example, when a novice monk receives full ordination, he enters the ordination platform, bows to the bhiká¹£u assembly, sincerely speaks and requests the preceptor, up to the first announcement, second announcement, and so on, all of which are called the preparatory stages of the good karmic paths.
At the end of the third announcement, in one instant, the manifest and unmanifest actions are called the fundamental karmic paths.
From then on, up to the recitation of the four refuges, and the subsequent manifest and unmanifest actions that continue to arise based on the previous, are all called the subsequent actions.
As explained above, not all karmic paths are completed by all three roots. By which roots are which karmic paths completed?
Verse:ğŸ”½Killing, harsh speech, and malice are all completed by hatred.
Stealing, sexual misconduct, and greed are all completed by greed.
Wrong views are completed by delusion. The remaining are accepted as completed by three.
Treatise:
In the evil destinies, the destinies of killing, harsh speech, and malice are completed by hatred, because when the mind of extreme cruelty and evil is present, these three are completed.
The three destinies of taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, and covetousness are completed by craving, because when the mind of extreme defilement is present, these three are completed.
Wrong views are completed only by delusion, because they are completed when the most serious delusion is present.

It is admitted that the three destinies of false speech, malicious speech, and frivolous speech are completed by each of the three roots, because when craving, hatred, etc., are present, each can complete these three.
Where are the destinies of evil karma produced?
Verse:
Sentient beings, form, name, and name-and-form are the places where they arise.
Treatise:
As explained above, the four sections of the destinies of karma are produced in the four places of sentient beings, etc., in order, by three, three, one, and three.

The three beginning with killing arise in the realm of sentient beings, the three beginning with stealing arise in the realm of objects, and only wrong view arises in the realm of names and forms. Lying, malicious speech, and frivolous speech arise in the realm of names, etc.

If one begins the performance with the definite intention to kill another, but dies either simultaneously with the one to be killed or before him, does one still incur the fundamental transgression of killing?
The verse states:
If one dies simultaneously or before, there is no fundamental transgression, because the basis is separate.
The treatise states:
If the killer dies simultaneously with the one to be killed or before him, he definitely does not incur the fundamental transgression.
Therefore, there is a question:
Can there be a killer who begins the performance of killing and brings it to completion, yet is not touched by the offense of killing?
It is said:
Yes.
How is it so?
It means the killer dies either simultaneously with the one to be killed or before him.
What is the reason for this?
Because the life of the being to be killed still exists, and it is not possible for the one who kills to incur the sin of killing.
It is not possible for the one who kills to incur the sin of killing when his life has already ended, because the basis of the sin is different.

That is, the body that was the basis of the preparatory action for killing has now been destroyed. Although there is a different type of body that is born in the same class, it is not the basis of the sin.
It is not reasonable for the principle of karmic retribution to be like this, since this [body] has never previously engaged in the preparatory action for killing.
If many people gather together in an army to kill enemies or hunt animals, and someone among them kills, which person incurs the sin of killing?
The verse states:
If they have the same intention, all are like the actual perpetrator.
The treatise states:
If in an army or other group, someone commits killing, all are like the actual perpetrator and incur the sin of killing, because they agree to the same action.
If one person kills and the others assist, they all receive the sin of killing.
If someone is forced to enter this situation, if they have the same mind as the one who kills, they also commit the sin of killing.

Only if someone makes a vow to save their own life and does not kill even in this situation, although they are forced by others to enter this situation, because they have no killing mind, they do not commit the sin of killing.
Next, we should discuss the characteristics of completing the karmic paths.
To what extent is it called killing?
To what extent is it called wrong view?
First, we distinguish the characteristics of killing. The verse says:
Killing is due to intentional thought, the thought of another, not mistakenly killing.
The treatise says:

It is necessary to first give rise to the intentional thought of wanting to kill. Towards other sentient beings, one has the thought of other sentient beings. One performs the karmic activity of killing without error.
That is to say, one only kills them and does not mistakenly kill others. This is called the karmic path of killing.
If one kills with doubt, it is also killing. That is, if one first has doubt about the object to be killed, thinking whether it is a living being or not,
or if it is a living being, whether it is that one or not,
and later makes a definite resolution, thinking whether it is that one or not, I will definitely kill it,
because the mind is without regard, if one kills a living being, it is also a karmic path.
How can killing be established in the aggregates that cease in a moment?

The breath wind is called life. It turns based on body and mind. If there is one who causes it to be cut off and not continue to arise, like extinguishing a lamp flame or the sound of a bell, it is called killing.
Or, life refers to the life faculty. If there is one who causes it to be cut off and not continue, it is called killing.
That is, if one has an evil mind and interrupts another's life, even for a single thought, it should not arise but does not arise. Only this, not anything else, is touched by the sin of killing.
To whom does the life that is cut off belong?
If there is no life, that person will die. Since it is designated as the sixth [consciousness], if it is not the self, to whom does it belong?
This will be extensively examined in the Treatise on Refuting the Self.
Therefore the World-Honored One said in a verse:
Life, heat, and consciousness, when these three leave the body,
The abandoned body lies still, like a piece of wood without thought.
Therefore, a body with faculties is called one with life, and without faculties it is called dead. This principle is certain.
The Ä€jÄ«vikas say: Killing without intention also results in the crime of killing.
Just like touching fire, even if not done intentionally, one will still be burned and harmed.
If so, then you should also commit a crime when encountering another's wife or accidentally touching her body.

Moreover, a person with good intentions pulling out an Ä€jÄ«vika's hair, or a teacher kindly encouraging ascetic practices, or due to a patron's indigestion from a previous meal, all of these should result in the crime of harming others.
Moreover, the fetus and the mother are mutually causes of suffering for each other, so the mother and the fetus should have the crime of harming others.
Moreover, since the one who is killed is combined with the killer, it should be like fire, which can burn its own support. One should not only allow the killer to commit a crime.
Also, if one sends another to kill, the sin of killing should be nonexistent, just as fire does not burn one who is told to touch it.
Also, all wood and so forth should be sinful objects, just as a house and so forth, because they also harm living beings when they collapse.
Also, it is not only a metaphor, but the meaning can be established.
The sin of killing has already been distinguished.
Stealing should be discussed next.
A verse says:
Stealing others' property is taking what is not given, by force or stealth, making it one's own.
The treatise says:
The previous non-mistaken, etc., as appropriate, flow to the later topics, so they are not repeated.

That is to say, one must first give rise to the intention to steal, regarding others' property, give rise to the thought of others' property, either by force or stealth, give rise to the activity of stealing, without mistake, take it, and make it one's own. This is called the sin of taking what is not given.

If one steals property from a stupa, one commits the sin of stealing from the Tathagata, because when the Buddha was about to enter nirvana, out of compassion for the world, he accepted all offerings.
Some other masters say:
If one hopes for protection,
if one digs up and takes an ownerless hidden treasure, one obtains the crime of theft in relation to the king.

If one steals objects that have been dedicated, if the ritual has been performed, one obtains the crime of theft in relation to the Sangha within the boundary. If the ritual has not been completed, one obtains the crime of theft in relation to all disciples of the Buddha.
The rest should be considered in the same way.
Stealing has been discussed.
Sexual misconduct will now be discussed.
A verse says:
Sexual misconduct is of four kinds, engaging in what should not be engaged in.
The treatise says:
In total there are four kinds of engaging in what should not be engaged in, all of which are called the crime of sexual misconduct:

1. Engaging in what should not be engaged in with regard to inappropriate objects, such as engaging with the wife of another who is protected by herself, by her parents, by her husband, or even by the king.
2. Engaging in what should not be engaged in with regard to inappropriate orifices, such as with one's own wife through the mouth or other orifices.
3. Engaging in what should not be engaged in with regard to inappropriate places, such as in a temple, a stupa, or an isolated place.
Fourth, engaging in sexual activity at inappropriate times.
What are inappropriate times?
They are times when a woman is pregnant, breastfeeding, or observing precepts.
Even with one's own wife and concubines, it is still sexual misconduct.
Some say:
If a husband has agreed to observe precepts, and then violates them, it is considered an inappropriate time.
Since one does not mistakenly speak, one also falls into this category.

If regarding another's wife one thinks she is one's own wife, or regarding one's own wife one thinks she is another's wife, or regarding the path one thinks it is not the path, etc., but one only has a mistaken mind, then even if one engages in sexual activity, it is not a karmic path.
If regarding this other's wife one thinks of another's wife, and engages in sexual misconduct, does one accomplish a karmic path?
Some say it is also accomplished, because one arouses sexual desire towards another's wife and enjoys it.
Some say it is not accomplished, just as in the karmic path of killing, one arouses the intention towards this [person], but brings it to completion towards another.

If she is already betrothed, from the one to whom she is betrothed;

Having explained sexual misconduct,
we should explain false speech.
A verse says:
Speaking with a defiled mind and a different intention, understanding the meaning is false speech.
The treatise says:
Speaking with a different intention from the meaning expressed, and the deceived person understanding the meaning expressed, with a defiled mind and without error, constitutes false speech.
If the deceived person does not yet understand the meaning of the words, what is this speech?
It is frivolous speech.
Since false speech is the speech that is uttered, and speech is composed of many syllables, at what time does it become a karmic path?
The manifest and unmanifest actions arising together with the last syllable and the path of action are established.
Or at whatever time the deceived person understands the meaning, the manifest and unmanifest actions of this path of action are established.

All that occurs together with the previous syllables is the preparation for this. At what time is the understanding of the meaning definitely based?ğŸ”½Is it said that when one has already heard and correctly understands it is called understanding?
Or is it said that when one is correctly hearing and is able to understand it is called understanding?
If so, what is the error?

If it is said that when one has already heard and correctly understands it is called understanding, and the meaning expressed is known by the mental consciousness, because the manifest speech and the auditory consciousness perish simultaneously, then this path of action should only be established as unmanifest action.

If it is said that when one is correctly hearing and is able to understand it is called understanding, although there is no error, it is still not clearly known how correct hearing can be called able to understand.

The one with good meaning and purpose has no confused conditions. The auditory consciousness that has already arisen is called able to understand, just as one without error should take as the main point.

The scriptures speak of sixteen kinds of words, namely, in regard to things that are not seen, not heard, not cognized, and not known, to say that one really sees, etc., or in regard to things that are seen, heard, cognized, and known, to say that one does not see, etc. These eight kinds are called non-holy words.

If in regard to things that are not seen up to not known, one says that one does not see, etc., or in regard to things that are seen up to known, one says that one really sees, etc., these eight kinds are called holy words.

Let us stop this digression and return to the main discussion.
Can one, by expressing a different meaning with the body, become guilty of false speech without uttering any words?

The false speech has been explained.
The remaining three kinds of speech should be explained.
The verse says:
Speech that destroys others with a defiled mind is called divisive speech.
Unpleasant and coarse speech is defiled and mixed with other defiled speech.
Others say that the three defiled [speech] are different: flattery, singing, and heretical treatises, etc.
The treatise says:
If defiled thoughts give rise to speech that destroys others, whether others are destroyed or not, it is all considered divisive speech.
Understanding the meaning without error flows into this category.
If with a defiled mind one utters unloving speech and reviles others, it is called harsh speech.
The defiled speech of the past flows into this, therefore understanding the meaning without error is also the same as before.
That is to say, the karmic path is only accomplished when the person one intends to scold understands the meaning of what is said.
All speech given rise to by defiled thoughts is called frivolous speech.
Why is this?
Because speech given rise to by defilements is all frivolous.
Only the previous word speech flows into this category.
Other masters say:
Apart from false speech and so forth, all speech given rise to by a defiled mind is called frivolous speech, which refers to flattery, singing, and wrong theories, etc.

Evil discourses refer to the extensive explanation and discussion of the words and phrases upheld by various incorrect views.
The same refers to the lamentations and various worldly frivolous discourses spoken with a defiled mind.
But they are all included in frivolous speech, which is spoken with a defiled mind that is different from the previous three.
When the wheel-turning king appears, there is also singing. Why is it not included in frivolous speech?
Because those words are spoken from a mind of renunciation, and can lead to renunciation, not to a defiled mind.
Other masters say:
At that time, there are also defiled words spoken in the context of marriage and so on, but because they are minor offenses, they do not constitute karmic paths.
